title: Checking Those Conditions!
question_text: In order to calculate a confidence interval to estimate a population proportion, which of the following is a correct check?

choices.text: To check that the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal, check that the number of successes is $n\hat{p}\leq 10$.
To check that the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal, check that the number of failures is $n\hat{p}\geq 10$.
To check for independence when sampling without replacement, check that $n\leq10\%N$.
To check for independence when sampling without replacement, check that the number of successes is $n\hat{p}\geq 10$.
To check that the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal, check that data was collected using a random sample or a randomized experiment.

solution:
Conditions must be checked when performing any test of significance or creating a confidence interval. In either case, you follow these four steps: - State (the parameter you will use or test) - Plan (the appropriate inference method you will use) - Do (perform your calculations) - Conclude (interpret your result).

Checking conditions occurs in the Plan step which you do in order to choose your test of significance or confidence interval.

In this problem, the correct answer states that it is important to make sure that the sample size is not larger than $10\%$ of the size of the population size in order to check for independence when estimating a population proportion.

So, Choice ‘C’ is correct.

Choice A is incorrect. It uses a ≤ sign when the true check looks for a value greater than or equal to 10.
